abstractText:
A modern Nepalese multi-text manuscript dated 1803 CE and containing four works: the Ratnamālāvadāna, the Dvāviṃśatyavadānakathā, a yet unidentified Work on the Dvādaśatīrthas of Nepal and the Upoṣadhāvadāna. The Ratnamālāvadāna is a collection of avadānas belonging to the cycle of king Aśoka and the monk Upagupta. Only 13 avadānas have been copied in this manuscript (number 1, 2, ,6, ,7, 8, 11, 13, 14, 18, 19, 25, 27 and 28 in Takahata's edition), and some of them are incomplete:

on f. 7v9 [= 35 verso], the Praśnottarāvadāna ends with stanza 7ab, sarvvasatvahitārthena śrāvastyāṃ va;
on f. 9r4 [= 43bis verso], the Hastakāvadāna (here called Hastāvadāna) ends with stanza 173abc (tenaiva bhujate(!) loke nānyena spṛśyate kvacit_ | abhuktaṃ kṣīyate [9r4] naiva);
on f. 9r4 [= 61 verso], the Śāntikāvadāna (also called Śāntiprakāraṇāvadāna and Praśāntakaraṇāvadāna (!)) has a lacuna corresponding to ca. the whole verso of the folio. In Takahata's editio princeps, the thirteenth avadāna is called Vaḍikāvadāna; however, an avadāna with the title Śāntikāvadāna is to be found in the manuscript labelled as B by Takahata [1954: v];
the Daśaśiro'vadāna has a lacuna stretching over ca. the whole verso of folio f. 34v10 [= 77 verso]. In the editio princeps, the fourteenth avadāna bears the title Gāndharvikāvadāna and seems to be a different text; an avadāna with the title Daśaśilāvadāna is to be found in the manuscript labelled as B by Takahata [1954: v];
the Somāvādāna ends abruptly on f. 5v7 [= 90 verso]. No avadāna with this title is to found title in the editio princeps; seemingly, the only manuscript of the Ratnamālāvadāna containing a story with this title is kept in the Tokyo University Library (No. 27 in Matsunami 1965: 216);
on f. 11r3 [= 101 recto] an avadāna starts with three lines of the cliché found at the beginning of each story;
an avadāna not found in the editio princeps starts on ff. 6v6 [= 107 verso], and ends abruptly after a few lines on ff. 7r6 [= 108 recto]

In fact, "the scribe seems to have transcribed what he could find in an imperfect copy; so he has written it [i.e. the Ratnamālāvadāna] in seven portions of 24, 12, 9, 34, 11, 18 and 7 leaves, respectively, making 109 leaves in all" (Bendall 1883: 139). This manuscript has not been used by Takahata for his editio princeps. The second work in the manuscript consists of the first five kathās from the Dvāviṃśatyavadānakathā (the last one is incomplete, and ends with stanza 8abc in Okada 1993: 19; stanza 41abc in Hahn 1983: 335); in the manuscript, it is called Dvāviṃśatidharmaratnāvadāna (both in the runnning marginal titles as well as in the final rubrics). The last two works are still unpublished (a summary of the content of the Upoṣadhāvadāna is provided in Mitra 1882: 265-7).
